original_statement: About three weeks ago my best friend gets kicked out of her house along with her child and she came to me for help. I gladly accepted her and her child to stay at my home rent free until she is ready to go on. My bestfriend and her husband had a huge falling out. I felt extremely guilty. I allowed her to stay at my house for three weeks now. All she has done for me is take and take from me without ever giving. I figured that she was hurt and not in a good place, so I allowed it. After day in and day out of her not cleaning after herself or her son, not helping around the house, and not being a decent roommate is where I feel like I could have done something.
para_statement: About three weeks ago, my best friend was forced to leave her home with her child and came to me for assistance. I welcomed them both to stay at my place rent-free until she was ready to move on. My best friend and her husband had a major disagreement. I felt a deep sense of responsibility. She has been staying with me for three weeks now, and all she has done is take from me without giving back. Understanding she was in a tough situation, I let it go. However, day after day, I've noticed she doesn't clean up after herself or her son, doesn't help around the house, and has not been a considerate roommate, making me feel that I should have handled things differently.

para_statement: About three weeks ago, my best friend and her child had to leave their home due to a conflict with her husband and sought my help. I offered them a place to stay at my house without any rent until she could get back on her feet. I felt a strong obligation to assist her during this difficult time. However, throughout the three weeks they've been with me, I've noticed she's been mostly relying on me without contributing back. I understand she was going through a tough period, so I initially overlooked it. Yet, day after day, I've observed that she neglects to tidy up after herself or her son, doesn't assist with house chores, and hasn't been a considerate roommate. This situation makes me wonder if I should have handled things differently from the start.

original_statement: Two weeks ago, we buried my mother in law. It was a sad day that day. My father had a few tears. My mother had a few more tears. My brothers and sisters all gave me a hug. I gave a speech about her life. She was an accountant. She always went to work with a smile. She always got the job done. She was the best accountant at the company. She had a few kids and a husband. They all loved her. She loved to eat cupcakes. She loved them if they had some sprinkles on them. We celebrated this by having a giant batch of cupcakes made for the burial. We all grabbed a cupcake and threw them into the grave before she was buried.
para_statement: Two weeks ago, we held the funeral for my mother-in-law. It was a somber occasion. My father shed some tears, and my mother cried even more. My siblings surrounded me with comforting hugs. I delivered a heartfelt speech about her life. She worked as an accountant, always showing up with a smile and completing her tasks efficiently. She was regarded as the best accountant in her company. She had a loving husband and children, who all adored her. She had a particular fondness for cupcakes, especially when they were topped with sprinkles. To honor her memory, we arranged for a large batch of cupcakes to be made for the funeral. We each took a cupcake and placed it in the grave before her burial.
